citations.narrative:
The facility did not have records demonstrating any of the acquisition information for the birds currently on-hand. An
Umbrella cockatoo, 2 Kookaburra, 1 Keel-billed toucan, 2 ducks, 3 chickens, 1 Eclectus parrot, 1 Shamrock macaw, and
60 Parakeets were listed on the facilities acquisition paperwork but name, address, and date acquired had not been filled
out. Complete and accurate animal records must be kept in order to facilitate tracing of animals in the event of an animal
disease outbreak. Records must be maintained that fully and correctly disclose information concerning all covered
animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, transported, sold, euthanized or otherwise disposed of
and shall include any offspring born while in the licensee's possession.
Correct by: 10/10/2023

There were approximately 3 bottles of cleaning solution stored adjacent and beneath a shelf in the bird food preparation
area. Spillage of toxic substances in food preparation areas represents a potential risk to the health and welfare of the
animals. Substances, such as cleaning supplies, that are harmful to the birds, but required for normal husbandry
practices, must not be in food storage and preparation areas. These substances may be stored in cabinets in the animal
areas, provided they are stored in properly labeled containers that are adequately secured to prevent potential harm to
the birds.
Correct by: 10/4/2023

The primary enclosure of a kookaburra had an open electrical socket inside its primary enclosure. The socket was along
the top edge of a back wall and a light fixture was plugged into 1 of the 2 sockets but the other was exposed within reach
of the bird. The bird was observed flying around the enclosure, and therefore had access to the electrical socket. An open
electrical socket cord could cause potential harm to the bird. The primary enclosure must be constructed and maintained
to protect the bird from injury.
Correct by: 10/4/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the assistant general manager.
Additional Inspectors:
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility did not have records demonstrating any of the acquisition information for the birds currently on-hand. An 
Umbrella cockatoo, 2 Kookaburra, 1 Keel-billed toucan, 2 ducks, 3 chickens, 1 Eclectus parrot, 1 Shamrock macaw, and 
60 Parakeets were listed on the facilities acquisition paperwork but name, address, and date acquired had not been filled 
out. Complete and accurate animal records must be kept in order to facilitate tracing of animals in the event of an animal 
disease outbreak. Records must be maintained that fully and correctly disclose information concerning all covered 
animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, transported, sold, euthanized or otherwise disposed of 
and shall include any offspring born while in the licensee's possession. 
 
Correct by: 10/10/2023 
3.150(e) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There were approximately 3 bottles of cleaning solution stored adjacent and beneath a shelf in the bird food preparation 
area. Spillage of toxic substances in food preparation areas represents a potential risk to the health and welfare of the 
animals. Substances, such as cleaning supplies, that are harmful to the birds, but required for normal husbandry 
practices, must not be in food storage and preparation areas. These substances may be stored in cabinets in the animal 
areas, provided they are stored in properly labeled containers that are adequately secured to prevent potential harm to 
the birds. 
 
Correct by: 10/4/2023 
3.153(a)(1)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The primary enclosure of a kookaburra had an open electrical socket inside its primary enclosure. The socket was along 
the top edge of a back wall and a light fixture was plugged into 1 of the 2 sockets but the other was exposed within reach 
of the bird. The bird was observed flying around the enclosure, and therefore had access to the electrical socket. An open 
electrical socket cord could cause potential harm to the bird. The primary enclosure must be constructed and maintained

to protect the bird from injury.  
 
Correct by: 10/4/2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the assistant general manager. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
